Incident.Summary: Traffic stop that led to a DUI arrest.

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText: L-28 is equipped with an MVR this incident was also recorded with my body-worn camera. Defendant: Bernard Nathinel Henry Jr Date of Birth: 06/23/1993 Date of Arrest: 11/19/2023 Time of Arrest: 1727 hours MD License #: MD10272268310 DUI #: 23-379 TRAINING/CERTIFICATES Trained in administering Standardized Field Sobriety Tests through the Maryland State Police and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration on December 5th-8th, 2022. Trained in administering Preliminary Breath Tests through the Maryland State Police Forensics Science Division on December 9, 2022. Trained in Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement through the Baltimore County Police DepartmentsTraffic Training Team on May 15-16, 2023. Vehicle in Motion (Phase 1): On November 19, 2023, at approximately 1704 hours, I, Trooper Stacey #7390 of the Maryland State Police Forestville barracks observed a gray Ford Fusion bearing VA registration TSM1866 traveling southbound on Capital Beltway prior to Pennsylvania Avenue in lane #4. As I positioned my vehicle behind the Ford Fusion, it immediately changed from lane #4 to lane #3. The Ford Fusion had a drivers side tail light inoperative. A METERS/NCIC check revealed the license plate that was displayed on the Ford Fusion were registered to another vehicle. At this time I initiated a traffic stop on the vehicle. The vehicle pulled over onto the right-hand shoulder. Personal Contact (Phase 2): Upon my drivers side approach of the vehicle I met with the driver who was identified by his Maryland ID as Bernard Nathinel Henry Jr (B/M, DOB: 06/23/1993), the vehicles registration plates that were issued to another vehicle were registered to Henry Jr. While speaking with Henry Jr, I detected a strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from the vehicle. Henry Jrs eyes were glassy and bloodshot. I asked Henry Jr where he was coming from, and he advised he was coming from the Washington Commanders football game. Henry Jr advised he consumed alcoholic beverages prior to the game. At this time I requested another unit for Standardized Field Sobriety Tests. Once the second unit arrived I asked Henry Jr to exit the vehicle to perform SFSTs to which he agreed. Pre-Arrest Screening (Phase 3): The evaluation was performed on the right shoulder of the highway. The weather was clear and approximately 60 degrees. Lighting conditions were dark. The ground was level and free of any debris. My patrol vehicles overhead emergency lights in the front were deactivated prior to field sobriety tests as well as the vehicles spotlight. Henry Jrwas wearing flat heeled shoes. Henry Jrappeared to be in good physical condition and did not display any visible signs of injuries. I asked Henry Jrthe following questions: Medical Conditions: None Glasses or contacts: No HORIZONTAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS (6/6 clues observed) The first test given was the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus test. The tip of my pen was used as the test stimulus and held approximately 12 inches from his eyes. Henry Jrwas instructed to look straight ahead, keeping his head still while following and focusing on the tip of the stimulus with his eyes. Henry Jrpupils were of equal size and showed equal tracking. Henry Jrdisplayed the following clues: Lack of Smooth Pursuit - Present in both eyes Distinct and Sustained Nystagmus at Maximum Deviation - Present in both eyes Onset of Nystagmus Prior to 45 Degrees - Present in both eye WALK AND TURN TEST (3/8 clues observed) Prior to Henry Jrperforming the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. Henry Jrwas instructed to place his right foot directly in front of his left foot and to touch heel to toe on an imaginary line. Henry Jrwas instructed and demonstrated to place his hands flat as his sides and to remain in that position until told to begin. Henry Jrwas advised to take nine (9) steps in a straight-line touching heel to toe on every step. Henry Jrwas instructed to keep his hands flat at his side, keep his eyes focused on his feet, and to count every step aloud. On the ninth step, Henry Jrwas explained and demonstrated to keep his lead foot on the line, and to take a series of small steps around with his rear foot to the left to turn completely around. Henry Jrwas again explained and demonstrated the series of nine (9) steps were to be performed identical to the first series, Henry Jrwas instructed that once he began the test that he was not to stop walking until the test was completed, keep his hands down by his sides, look down at his feet, and count each step aloud. Henry Jradvised he understood the test. Instructional Stage: Cannot keep balance during instructions Walking Stage (1st set of nine steps): margin-bottom:19px">Misses heel to toe margin-bottom:19px">Uses arms for balance Walking Stage (2nd set of nine steps): margin-bottom:19px">Misses heel to toe margin-bottom:19px">Actual steps taken ONE LEG STAND (2/4 clues observed) Prior to Henry Jrperforming the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. He was instructed to stand with his feet together and hands down by his side while the instructions were given. During the test he was instructed not to begin the test until he was instructed to start, once the test had been demonstrated. When instructed to start, he was to raise the foot of his choice off the ground approximately 6 inches. While his leg was raised he was to keep his leg straight, watch his raised foot, and to count out loud by thousands (one thousand-one, one thousand-two) and to continue the test until told to stop. Henry Jradvised he understood the instructions given. Henry Jrdisplayed the following clues: Puts foot down: 0 to 10 11 to 20 21 to 30 Use arms for balance: 0 to 10 11 to 20 21 to 30 Henry Jrwas offered a Preliminary Breath Test to which he agreed with results of .13 BrAC ARREST: Based off of the following, I had reason to believe Henry Jrwas operating a motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol: Odor of an alcoholic beverage on his breath Eyes glassy and bloodshot Admission of consuming alcohol prior to driving Clued observed during field sobriety Henry Jrwas arrested at 1727 hours and transported to the Maryland State Police Forestville Barrack. At approximately 1731 hours, Henry Jrwas read the DR15 Advice of Rights played aloud via the MVA website English audio recording. Henry Jrrefused to take the intoximeter examination test at 1740 hours. Henry Jrwas given the appropriate citations and all pertinent paperwork and released to a friend at 1809 hours. All of the above events occurred in Prince Georges County, Maryland.
